title: Obama, GOP spar ahead of new EPA pollution rules
content:
The EPA will roll out landmark greenhouse gas restrictions for power plants Monday . Obama , GOP spar on new EPA rules
President Barack Obama and Republicans squared over pollution regulations in their weekly radio addresses to the nation Saturday morning ahead of Monday ’ s rollout of landmark EPA greenhouse gas restrictions for power plants .
Obama , who taped his address Friday at the Children ’ s National Medical Center in Washington , D.C. focused on the impacts of climate change and air pollution on public health .
“ As president , and as a parent , I refuse to condemn our children to a planet that ’ s beyond fixing , ” Obama said , who spoke after visiting children at the hospital who were being treated for asthma and other breathing problems .
“ Often , these illnesses are aggravated by air pollution – pollution from the same sources that release carbon and contribute to climate change . And for the sake of all our kids , we ’ ve got to do more to reduce it , ” he said .
Obama will further drive that point home on Monday in a conference call with American Lung Association and other health groups Monday after the new rule is officially unveiled by EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy .
But Wyoming Sen. Mike Enzi , said in the weekly GOP address that the administration “ has set out to kill coal and its 800,000 jobs . ”
Wyoming is the nation ’ s biggest coal producer , contributing nearly 40 percent of the U.S. coal mined in 2013 , and it had the third lowest electricity price in the country , according to the Energy Information Administration .
If the administration “ succeeds in death by regulation , we ’ ll all be paying a lot more money for electricity – if we can get it , ” said Enzi , who also cited the administration ’ s delays in approving the Keystone XL oil pipeline .
“ We all want clean air and clean water , ” he added . “ We don ’ t want costly regulations that make little or no difference , that are making things less affordable . Republicans want electricity and gas when you need it , at a price you can afford . ”
Some coal-state Democrats — including those in some of the toughest races this year — have distanced themselves from Obama ’ s EPA agenda . One of the most endangered incumbent Democrats , Rep. Nick Rahall ( D-W.Va. ) , took to the House floor Thursday to preemptively attack Monday ’ s proposed rule for hurting coal miners and their communities .
“ At stake is our economy and the livelihoods of our coal miners , our steelworkers , electrical workers , those who keep our freight trains running , and families and businesses that rely on affordable energy from coal , ” Rahall said . Obama didn ’ t mention coal in his weekly address Saturday .
But Obama said Republicans are repeating the same unfounded warnings about jobs and energy prices they brought up against prior environmental laws .
“ Special interests and their allies in Congress will claim that these guidelines will kill jobs and crush the economy . Let ’ s face it , that ’ s what they always say , ” Obama said . “ But every time America has set clear rules and better standards for our air , our water , and our children ’ s health – the warnings of the cynics have been wrong . ”
He said “ excuses for inaction somehow suggest a lack of faith ” in how businesses can adapt .
“ The truth is , when we ask our workers and businesses to innovate , they do . When we raise the bar , they meet it , ” Obama said . He cited the rules that eliminated lead in fuels , cancer-causing plastics , led to better refrigerators and air conditioners and a “ retooled ” U.S. auto industry that faced higher fuel efficiency standards and are now “ selling the best cars in the world . ”
EPA standards , Obama said , “ were created in an open and transparent way , with input from the business community , ” and the state and local governments that are already implementing regional cap-and-trade and other carbon-reduction programs .
“ So the idea of setting higher standards to cut pollution at our power plants is not new . It ’ s just time for Washington to catch up with the rest of the country , ” he said .
